title: Respect During Conflict
description: Explore how respect is maintained during disagreements

questions.text: Even when we're upset, we treat each other with basic respect.

therapeutic.rationale: Maintaining respect during conflict is a relationship baseline. Anger doesn't justify disrespect. Couples who hold this line protect their foundation even in difficult moments.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If respect breaks down during conflict, identify specific behaviors that cross the line. Creating clear boundaries about what's not acceptable helps.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual commitment to respect during conflict protects your relationship.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What does respect during conflict look like for you? When has it been missing?

questions.text: I feel safe from hurtful words even when we're upset with each other.

therapeutic.rationale: Name-calling and hurtful language inflict wounds that outlast the argument. These words are hard to unhear and erode trust over time.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If hurtful language occurs, it needs direct attention. The speaking partner must understand the damage; the receiving partner deserves an apology and commitment to change.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual avoidance of hurtful language protects your emotional safety.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Have hurtful words been used in your conflicts? What impact have they had?

questions.text: I still feel valued as a person even when my partner disagrees with me.

therapeutic.rationale: Disagreement about issues shouldn't translate to devaluation of the person. Feeling valued even during conflict reflects secure attachment.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If disagreement feels like devaluation, explore what creates that feeling. Tone? Words? Or internal interpretation? Both external and internal factors can be addressed.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual feeling of being valued during disagreement creates security.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Do you feel valued during disagreements? What would help?

questions.text: We don't bring up past mistakes to win current arguments.

therapeutic.rationale: Kitchen-sinking—bringing in past grievances—derails current discussions and signals that past issues aren't truly resolved. It also feels disrespectful and unfair.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If past issues keep surfacing, they may need dedicated attention. Bringing them up in current fights suggests they're still unhealed.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared commitment to staying on topic creates focused, resolvable conflict.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Do past issues get brought into current conflicts? What might that mean?

questions.text: I trust my partner won't use my vulnerabilities against me in a fight.

therapeutic.rationale: Using shared vulnerabilities as weapons is a profound betrayal. Trust that intimate knowledge won't be weaponized is essential for continued openness.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If vulnerabilities have been weaponized, this needs serious repair. The offending partner must understand the breach of trust they've created.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual trust that vulnerabilities are safe creates deep security.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Do you trust your partner with your vulnerabilities, even during conflict?
